alt-summary-body.p: Nightly protests continued here through the weekend as residents, police and demonstrators brace for a decision from a grand jury set to reconvene Monday.

headline.main-hed: Ferguson grand jury to reconvene Monday
Ferguson Grand Jury Set to Reconvene

summary-body.p: Nightly protests continued here through the weekend as residents, police and demonstrators brace for a decision from a grand jury set to reconvene Monday.

headline.main-hed: Ferguson Grand Jury Set to Reconvene

media.media-caption: Tensions in Ferguson, Mo., and the surrounding region remain high in anticipation of a verdict from the grand jury in the shooting death of Michael Brown. Photo: AP

article-body.p: FERGUSON, Mo.—Protests continued here through the weekend as residents, police and demonstrators brace for a decision from a grand jury set to reconvene Monday in the case of a racially charged police shooting that brought weeks of unrest over the summer.

On Sunday, protesters renewed complaints about the secretive grand jury process when a St. Louis County court administrator released an open letter that said documents related to the case would not necessarily be released to the public.

“If the grand jury returns a no true bill, the judge anticipates the court will receive requests for grand jury records,” said Paul Fox, court administrator in the letter. “The court will thereafter be guided by the law in its response to requests for grand jury records.”

Robert McCulloch, the St. Louis County prosecutor, who convened the grand jury, had pledged to push for the release of as many documents as possible related to the case if the grand jury does not indict Ferguson Police Officer Darren Wilson in the Aug. 9 shooting death of unarmed teenager Michael Brown.

media.media-caption: A pedestrian passes a boarded up storefront in Ferguson on Sunday.

article-body.p: “I think if you let a little sunlight in, people would stop criticizing the grand jury process,” said Patricia Bynes who has had a leading voice among protesters especially in the days after Mr. Brown’s death. But, she said, the delay in the grand jury process could be evidence that jurors are closely weighing evidence. “I feel a lot more confident now that I know that grand jury is actually looking over things.”

Meanwhile, as protests continued police honed their response to the crowds. On Saturday night, protests in front of the Ferguson Police Department led to two more arrests even as St. Louis County Police leaders tried a less-confrontational approach that cooled tempers but did not eliminate conflict.

During past nights’ civil disobedience, police simply formed into skirmish lines while wearing riot gear and pushed into crowds to make arrests after a few warnings announced over loudspeakers. But beginning Friday, police started using less-confrontational tactics, eschewing shotguns with nonlethal rounds they had carried earlier in the week. Many officers on Saturday wore standard patrol uniforms, rather than crowd-control gear.
Lt. Jerry Lohr was in charge of crowd-control Saturday and began the night by employing a simple tactic: coming out to talk with protesters and answer their questions.

“This is the way it should have been from the beginning,” said Markelina McGruder from St. Louis. She said just having the police speak with protesters does a great deal to ease tensions. “Have a good night,” Lt. Lohr said to her as he walked away. “Be safe,” she replied.

Lt. Lohr even fielded a delicate question from 21-year-old Justin Giuliano, who asked if events over the past few months might have been different if the officer had not been white and Mr. Brown had not been African-American. “It may be. I don’t know,” said Lt. Lohr. “Those are tough questions.”

Despite the congeniality, two people were arrested for unlawful assembly, including one reporter from an independent news organization who was arrested while standing on the sidewalk. A police spokesman said they are looking into the circumstances of his arrest.

On Sunday, The American Civil Liberties Union issued a statement critical of the arrest. “Police are not allowed to threaten to arrest or order individuals to move who are peaceably standing, marching or assembling on public sidewalks in Ferguson,” said Tony Rothert, legal director of the Missouri branch of the ACLU.

All across the St. Louis area, people continued to board up and barricade businesses and government buildings. Police stations in Ferguson, St. Louis and Clayton—where the grand jury is meeting—have all been barricaded.

Some freshly boarded-up shops have euphemistic signs on them meant to blunt the negative image those precautions taken by their owners convey. One jeweler in Clayton placed a poster on the boards covering the shop’s windows saying: “Still open during construction.” The shop’s owners declined to comment on the precautions, saying they feared bad publicity.
As of early Sunday evening heavy rain deterred protesters and no one stood across from the Ferguson Police station. But a few cases of bottled water had been carefully staged for later in the night
Write to Ben Kesling at benjamin.kesling@wsj.com
